title: What will be the Chinese renminbi's share as a global payments currency in December 2021, according to SWIFT?
preds: Adamant that bin 1 is likeliest. If right, perhaps because I visualized the data. If wrong, perhaps I was unlucky or perhaps I just misjudged.

It's going to come out at either 1.99% or 2.01% it seems.
Long term trend is "up", seasonal pattern indicates a decline in Dec v Nov. Political pressure on China and global trade disruptions to me speak for bin 1 as an exception to the trend pattern. However, this forecast is a hedge for overweighting bin 1 earlier.

Not intuitive to me that it went up for November because I thought the Chinese housing crisis would further erode confidence in the renminbi, and the Fed’s increasingly aggressive policy to combat inflation would also decrease the international appetite for renminbi and increase interest in holding the US dollar. If anyone has an idea why the holdings of renminbi increased so much in November, let me know. October could have been an outlier month, but I felt like something was fundamentally changing, and I guess (at least for November) my assumptions were incorrect.
Back up above 2 in November. Increasing on 2 to 2.5.
Tweaking a bit toward the crowd, but I think the below 2% option is being significantly underweighted.

No rationale or input here but just an interesting observation I'd like to highlight: the crowd median is almost 3x more confident than I am in second bin. I think bin 1 is more than 10x more likely than the crowd median. I was brought here by GJO email alerting me these challenges are about to end so I'd thought I'd contribute one final time(s).

On the one hand below 2% is more common in the longer history, but on the other recent numbers had been pretty consistently a bit above 2% until the October number dropped below. So I'm still favoring 2 to 2.5% a bit but going up 27 on below 2%.
Narrowing on 2 to 2.5 as recent months have been firmly in that range and fairly consistent.

This forecast is based on:
1-China's debt to African & S.American countries and other will push Rinminbi above. 2-the currwn y is likely to be t
Asia's central currency
https://asia.nikkei.com/Editor-s-Picks/Interview/China-s-yuan-likely-to-become-Asia-s-central-currency-Kenneth-Rogoff&ved=2ahUKEwiL6sjfvabyAhUz5uAKHZIqD40QxfQBMAB6BAgMEAM&usg=AOvVaw1oxduh9Y71xXvvjB-OZTFL
2.46% in June. Pretty big jump and seems like it's pretty noisy lately so spreading out my distribution a bit. -5 on less than 2 and + 9 on 2.5 to 3.
The Renminbi is a currency on the move. The Russians need a replacement currency for the US dollar.

"But that outcome is far from guaranteed. China’s reform agenda is already languishing, tariffs and other trade curbs are disrupting access to global markets and advanced technologies, and Covid stimulus has lifted debt to record levels" https://au.finance.yahoo.com/news/china-rule-world-maybe-never-210013340.html
What's the case for so little on below 2%?

Would expect a further increase via e-commerce platform but not sure this needs in fact to be true.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-24/how-xi-and-the-ccp-turned-on-jack-ma-ant-and-china-s-fintech-companies?cmpid=BBD062521_CAS&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=210625&utm_campaign=closeasia&sref=1mjpCW3y
Actually coming down on 2.5 to 3, I don't know why we're putting so much weight on above 2.5 when it's never before broken 2.5%, especially since it looks like it may have reverted to the mean now.
Last two months are both under 2%. Not sure why it spiked in the months prior but still weighting more heavily around the typical values in the last couple years.

extreme cases are undervalued. A medium-sized loss in the euro's share could push the renminbi above 3%. The Chinese recovery is a big question mark atm, but the CNY has had several half-point MoM jumps in the past year. Can't rule much out
Coming down a bit on last months lower number. I thought reversion to the mean was likely but that was a pretty sudden drop, curious to see what the next few months look like.

According to the source material it's driven pretty heavily by Hong Kong (about 75%) so that leads me to believe there's a lot of potential for noise and fluctuations. I think the possibility for reversion to the mean is pretty large too, in 2018 it reached the lower 2% range for several months before returning to the upper 1% range. That said, I think as China's economy grows there is potential for it to continue to gain in share, so plenty of possibility for it to steadily go up. And the series is pretty noisy, with a low of 1.65% in the last couple of years and a high of 2.49% (last month).
Checked the April 2021 ppt in the link in the description. Latest figure (March 2021): 2.49%.
THE CHINEESE CURRENCY IS NON-CONVERTABLE ON THE OPEN MARKET, AND IS UNLIKELY TO BE SO IN THE FORSEEABLE FUTURE.

A bit more conservative with my forecast https://www.gulf-times.com/story/689415/China-not-to-replace-dollar-with-digital-yuan-PBoC While China has made strides in developing its financial markets, allowing the value of its currency to be set by market forces and allowing capital to flow more freely, there’s little reason to expect it to quickly adopt the sort of Western institutions that global investors seek out as an environment for protecting their savings
A good article
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/will-chinas-new-digital-yuan-threaten-king-dollars-reign-11617743063

Finance is one of the fastest changing aspects of the Chinese economy, also one of the areas they have the greatest catch-up. Fintech is booming, Hong Kong political fate had been decided, so there are few obstacles to rapid growth of Chinese goals
China's currency importance will increase but USA will try to minimize its impact
They won't use SWIFT to dethrone the greenback, it is electronic apps that they will use to push the use of their currency
RMB representation drops and then China announces that it will develop its own SWIFT system for its regional trading partners. And then it's on like Donkey Kong!

In order to forecast the share of Renmimbi, 2 points need to be considered. 1. Advancement of digital Yuan
2. Belt-Road-Initiative. China has initiated number of projects such as DCEP (Digital Currency Electronics Platform), waiver of transaction fees between Yuan and 12 other currencies. Its BRI will make acceptance of Yuan for loan payments, etc. and its DCEP will provide an alternative for US sanctions. China is very ambitious and will accelerate acceptance of Yuan in global payments.  https://techwireasia.com/2021/03/can-chinas-digital-yuan-overtake-the-dollar-as-the-top-global-currency/

It is rising, they are in spitting distance of the JPY. 
Caveat: The leadership is very erratic.

I see the renmimbi share advancing at an accelerated pace, hence my base case of > 2.5% although this is relatively low conviction given the short time horizon so I remain a large weight on the current bracket of 2-2.5%

With the development of China's economy, China are playing a  increasing role of dealing with international issues. In some way, the payments currency reflects on power of a country. Concerning the status of China now, I think the percent of "RMB's share as a global payments currency"  is very likely to be between 2.00% and 2.50%, and it tends to 2.50%.

Looking at the SWIFT report and the longer term picture on page 7 (see the link), one can see that there is not much of a trend there. The average is around 2% and it can be below or above it in December 2021. Hard to say at this stage.
https://www.swift.com/our-solutions/compliance-and-shared-services/business-intelligence/renminbi/rmb-tracker/rmb-tracker-document-centre

Moving massive markets is difficult, and being at 2.20% splits the middle closely of the 2-2.5 category.  China's growth will be stagnated by their perceived political actions.  I also don't believe we'll see a massive drop either.  Much of this also depends on the EU and North America applying economic pressure due to those perceived political actions.

This is a dangerous question. Read different news outlets describing foreign states forming democracies. What is the definition of democracy in Hong Kong? I remember a few years ago China wanted to start their own international court after a ruling from the international court decided to support the Philippines. The UK had BREXIT yet they have always maintained their own currency. What are the odds Asia would come up with their own version of the Euro. I’m sure this may have come up in the past maybe. What is Asia’s strategic goals for Asia? I’m just a registered nurse. However, I have learned as a nurse empathy. What is empathy. It’s not sympathy. Empathy is imagining what your pt is going through. Post WW2 systems have worked well. Liberalism has a place in the world but who is going define it?  I suppose we will find out soon enough. Old deals have been changed, modified, cheated, destroyed, renegotiated etc. the dollar has supported international trade and international systems for the last generation. The United States is not that evil. Their are lots of foreign state actors attempting to make the USA look one way or another.  I assume even from the inside. Maybe a great fleshing can be avoided but I’m not holding my breath.
2.5% seems a good point estimate, maybe a bit higher if they are going to push it. However, I do not see this as a particularly volatile number and see it as a lot of work to increase it drastically.
The Chinese economy is always increasing.

Given that the uptrend in RMB as a global payments currency is not noise and fully intended, I see the trend continuing as China expands its geopolitical influence. This isn't something happening rapidly though (a quick glance at the SWIFT report shows a +0.35% YoY increase in February), especially given the suspicion and mistrust surrounding Chinese foreign policy and influence in developed countries. Extrapolating the YoY trend linearly gets us to 2.52% as a basic guess. Given Metcalfe's law, I'm going to lean a bit on the higher end, but otherwise don't have a reason to prefer a higher or lower estimate.

Would someone be willing to share the reason why the crowd forecast for the "Less than 2.00%" bucket is lower than the "Between 2.00% and 2.50%, inclusive" bucket? The base rates I calculated (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1261696) suggests to me that it should be the other way around.

Using data from the slide titled "Evolution of RMB’s share as a global payments currency" in SWIFT_RMB_Tracker_March 2021_Slides.pdf (slide 7/10)  Average of monthly data from Jan 2018 to Feb 2021 is 1.96. 
Min is 1.56 (Feb 2018). 
Max is 2.42 (Jan 2021).  38 months of data.
For 28/38 (0.74) months it was less than 2.00%. 
For 10/38 (0.26) months it was between 2.00% and 2.50%, inclusive. If we limit ourselves to months since (and including) Jan 2020, then there are 14 months of data.
For 10/14 (0.71) months it was less than 2.00%. 
For 4/14 (0.29) months it was between 2.00% and 2.50%, inclusive.

Research shows that the use of a currency for global transactions depends most importantly on trust rather than just economic strength or power.
It is clear that China’s economic power is not an indication of its banking system and its minimal use in the global economy.
China’s ambition to advance the RMB as an International currency has been stunted by its geopolitical actions such as territorial disputes in the South China sea and the Indian/Chinese border, the Status of Hong Kong and threats against Taiwan and created mistrust. 
An adoption of the RMB relies on the trust and confidence of providing a stable, stable and reliable haven with no geopolitical risk which is a difficult sell by the Chinese government. 
Domestically China has a large unregulated shadow banking system that is indicative of a mature financial system.
The People’s bank of China has been developing the digital Yuan to replace physical cash. This will allow the Government to own the ledger that records and traces every transaction via blockchain technologies by freely conducting surveillance of any data travelling through the system. This would probably diminish the appeal to the citizens of developed nations who desire a degree of privacy.
Therefore I will suggest that the RMB’s share of global payments currency to remain at its current low level.
